bestBHT.bht: The address gradually shifts to the Jews, who pronounced condemnation on Gentiles as sinners. However, their act of judging is unjustifiable, as they themselves were guilty of the same sins they criticized. The passage highlights the hypocrisy of condemning others while indulging in the same offenses. It reminds us that judging others does not absolve us of our own guilt and cautions against hasty judgment. The verse underscores the importance of examining ourselves before criticizing others, for we are without excuse when we engage in the very same behaviors.

Henry Alford: The address passes gradually to the Jews. They were the people who judged—who pronounced all Gentiles to be born in sin and under condemnation.
This is evident by comparing the charge, 'thou that judgest does the same things,' with verses 21–23, where the same charge is implied in a direct address to the Jew.
Therefore thy setting thyself up as a judge is unjustifiable.
Albert Barnes: Since you Jews condemn the Gentiles for their sins, on the ground that they have the means of knowing their duty, therefore, you who are far more favored than they, are entirely without an excuse for the same things.
It often happens, too, that people are remarkably zealous in opposing those offences which they themselves secretly practice.

Remarkable zeal against sin may be no proof of innocence; the zeal of persecutors, and often of pretended reformers, may be far from proof that they are free from the very offences which they are condemning in others.
Marvin Vincent: O man. General, but still with a general and slightly reproachful reference to the Jew.
Judgest [κρινων] . With the sense of condemning.
John Calvin: Though thou consented not to the vices of others, and seemest to be avowedly even an enemy and a reprover of vices; yet as thou art not free from them, if thou really examinest thyself, thou canst not bring forward any defense.
Thou art doubly deserving of condemnation; for thou art guilty of the same vices which thou blamest and reprovest in others.
Though thou judgest, thou yet doest the same things.
Philip Schaff: Without excuse; as in chap. Romans 1:20
The judgment pronounced upon others applies to the man's own conduct.
The censorious spirit is of the same sinful character as vice.
John Gill: Therefore thou art inexcusable, O man...such could never be justified before God by their works, but might be justly condemned by him.

they...thought themselves to be righteous persons, and justified in the sight of God; and who, though they were secretly guilty of many abominable iniquities, yet were very severe upon the sins of others, and therefore inexcusable.

the words respect every man, of whatsoever nation, office, or place; and may be particularly applied to hypocrites, and seem designed to correct censoriousness, and hasty judging, and to throw confusion on such who value themselves on being the censurers and reprovers of others.
John Wesley: Therefore — The apostle now makes a transition from the gentiles to the Jews, till, at Romans 2:6, he comprises both.
Thou art inexcusable — Seeing knowledge without practice only increases guilt.
For in that thou judgest the other — The heathen. Thou condemnest thyself; for thou doest the same things — In effect; in many instances.

bhtAttempts.bht: The address of Romans 2:1 gradually shifts to the Jews, who were notorious for their judgment of Gentiles, condemning them as sinners. This condemnation was unjustifiable, as the Jews themselves were guilty of the same sins they condemned. The verse emphasizes that the act of judging others does not absolve one of their own guilt. Even though the Jews may have thought themselves righteous and justified before God, their secret indulgence in abominable iniquities made them inexcusable. This passage serves as a caution against hypocritical and hasty judgment, reminding us that knowledge without corresponding actions only increases guilt.

The address gradually shifts to the Jews, the people who condemned Gentiles for their sins. However, their act of judging is unjustifiable, as they themselves were guilty of the same sins they criticized. The passage highlights the hypocrisy of condemning others while indulging in the same offenses. It reminds us that judging others does not absolve us of our own guilt and cautions against hasty judgment. The verse emphasizes that knowledge without corresponding actions only increases guilt.

The address transfers to the Jews, who pronounced condemnation on Gentiles as sinners. However, their judgment is unjustifiable, as they are guilty of the same sins. This highlights the hypocrisy of condemning others while engaging in the same offenses. The verse cautions against hasty judgment and reminds us that knowledge without corresponding actions only increases guilt. It serves as a vital reminder that judging others does not excuse our own wrongdoing.

The focus shifts to the Jews, who judged and condemned the Gentiles for their sins. However, their own guilt is evident as they commit the same offenses. This highlights the hypocrisy of criticizing others while engaging in the very actions they condemn. The verse serves as a caution against hasty judgment, reminding us that knowledge without corresponding actions only adds to our guilt. It emphasizes that judging others doesn't excuse our own wrongdoing, for we are without excuse.

The address gradually shifts to the Jews, who pronounced condemnation on Gentiles as sinners. However, their act of judging is unjustifiable, as they themselves were guilty of the same sins they criticized. The passage highlights the hypocrisy of condemning others while indulging in the same offenses. It reminds us that judging others does not absolve us of our own guilt and cautions against hasty judgment. The verse underscores the importance of examining ourselves before criticizing others, for we are without excuse when we engage in the very same behaviors.
